'''Racism in Canada''' traces both historical and contemporary [[racist]] community attitudes, as well as governmental negligence and political non-compliance with United Nations human rights standards and incidents in [[Canada]].<ref name="OHCHR">{{cite web |title=International Convention on the Elimination of A ll Forms of Racial and Sexual Discrimination |url=http://docstore.ohchr.org/SelfServices/FilesHandler.ashx?enc=6QkG1d%2fPPRiCAqhKb7yhsoFZxvnsZjtq1Xnb4bcEJClA0kmqJQeV0zdR93%2ffv7%2fBSAkon8Nc2CMTKCBgv25nw5etVi%2bkUMR9abtAFqi1lgW095I%2btkhuhVTozo2kfkhQV78slhAW5U9xPBqn413aeA%3d%3d |website=Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights |accessdate=22 October 2020|date=13 September 2010}}</ref> Contemporary Canada is the product of indigenous [[First Nations]] combined with multiple waves of immigration, predominantly from [[Asia]] and [[Europe]].
==Overview== In general, [[White Canadians]] consider themselves to be mostly free of [[Racism|racial prejudice]], perceiving the country to be a more inclusive society, a notion that has come under criticism.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jul/12/canada-black-lives-matter-indigenous-people-muslims|title=Canada is hailed for its tolerance but is it ready to confront its racism?|last=Kassam|first=Ashifa|date=2016-07-12|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-12-06|archive-date=June 12, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190612154417/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jul/12/canada-black-lives-matter-indigenous-people-muslims|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/crime/2015/07/21/no-charges-against-peel-police-in-death-of-jermaine-carby.html|title=No charges against Peel police in death of Jermaine Carby | The Star|website=thestar.com|access-date=October 7, 2020|archive-date=September 3, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200903105624/https://www.thestar.com/news/crime/2015/07/21/no-charges-against-peel-police-in-death-of-jermaine-carby.html|url-status=live}}</ref> For instance, the [[Aboriginal peoples in Canada|Aboriginal]] population in Canada has been treated badly and sustained major hardships.<ref>Terry Glavin, [https://ottawacitizen.com/opinion/columnists/glavin-canadians-have-no-reason-to-be-smug-about-race "Canadians have no reason to be smug about race"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180704092855/http://ottawacitizen.com/opinion/columnists/glavin-canadians-have-no-reason-to-be-smug-about-race |date=July 4, 2018 }} (November 2014), ''The Ottawa Citizen''</ref> These perceptions of inclusion and "[[Color blindness (race)|colour-blindness]]" have been challenged in recent years, with scholars such as [[Constance Backhouse]] stating that white supremacy is still prevalent in the country's legal system, with blatant racism created and enforced through the law.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Colour-coded: A Legal History of Racism in Canada, 1900–1950|last=Backhouse|first=Constance|publisher=The Osgoode Society for Canadian Legal History|year=1999|isbn=|location=Toronto|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref> According to one commentator, Canadian "racism contributes to a self-perpetuating cycle of criminalization and imprisonment".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://torontolife.com/city/life/skin-im-ive-interrogated-police-50-times-im-black/|title=The Skin I'm In: I've been interrogated by police more than 50 times—all because I'm black|date=April 21, 2015|access-date=October 7, 2020|archive-date=October 24, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181024073606/https://torontolife.com/city/life/skin-im-ive-interrogated-police-50-times-im-black/|url-status=live}}</ref> In addition, throughout Canada's history there have been laws and regulations that have negatively affected a wide variety of races, religions, and groups of persons.<ref name=McGill></ref><ref name="Canada 1885">''Statutes of Canada. An Act of Respecting and Regulating Chinese Immigration into Canada, 1885. Ottawa: SC 48–49 Victoria, Chapter 71''</ref><ref>{{cite hansard | url=http://www2.parl.gc.ca/HousePublications/Publication.aspx?DocId=1659497&Language=E&Mode=1&Parl=38&Ses=1 | title=Chinese Canadian Recognition and Restitution Act | house=House of Commons, Canada | date=2005-04-18 | page=1100 }}</ref>
Canadian law uses the term "[[visible minority]]" to refer to [[people of colour]] (but not aboriginal Canadians), introduced by the [[Employment equity (Canada)|Employment Equity Act of 1995]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Employment Equity Act (1995, c. 44) |url=http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/E-5.401/50293.html/?noCookie |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070212153447/http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/E-5.401/50293.html/?noCookie |archivedate=February 12, 2007 }}</ref> However, the UN Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination stated this term may be considered objectionable by certain minorities and recommended an evaluation of this term.<ref>{{cite web|title=Report of the Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination|url=http://www2.ohchr.org/english/bodies/cerd/docs/A.67.18%20English.pdf|website=United Nations|publisher=United Nations: Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination|accessdate=4 March 2017|archive-date=April 11, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190411143230/https://www2.ohchr.org/english/bodies/cerd/docs/A.67.18%20English.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref>
In 2020, Canadian university students attracted media attention by sharing on Instagram their experiences of racism on campuses.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Bowden|first=Olivia|date=10 September 2020|title=Canadian university students use Instagram to reveal racism on campuses|work=CBC|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/canada-universities-racism-instagram-1.5716603|url-status=live|access-date=|archive-date=October 3, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201003205849/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/canada-universities-racism-instagram-1.5716603}}</ref>
=== Cansplaining === Similarly, a term that has been labelled as "Cansplaining" is when an article, column, or report in a media publication both domestic and international offers a definitive explanation about Canada. It’s often written by a [[Canadian]] — a "Cansplainer", and its tone overflows with confidence about the country. It tends to provide a grand unified theory of Canada, representing a desire to control the country’s reputation in order to convince about politics and public policy, using Canada as a metaphor, case study and controlled experiment.<ref name=JJMc>{{Cite news|last=J.J|first=McCullough|date=13 July 2018|title=Cansplaining 101: How to write about Canada|work=[[The Washington Post]]|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/global-opinions/wp/2018/07/13/cansplaining-101-how-to-write-about-canada/|url-status=live|url-access=subscription}}</ref>
Such works are usually exaggerated or flattering, and it presents Canada as a country that has solved big challenges commonly faced in the world — such as immigration and healthcare — better than anyone else. At the same time, topics such as the Canadian economy or trends in employment, infrastructure, housing are rarely discussed or mentioned. Recently, this often takes the form of praising Canada’s apparent immunity to movements such as the rising [[right-wing nationalism]] seen in other [[Western world|Western countries]], particularly the [[United States]] during the [[Trump administration]].<ref name=JJMc></ref>
==Examples==
=== [[First Nations]] === {{See also|Gustafsen Lake standoff|Burnt Church Crisis|Grand River land dispute|Ipperwash Crisis|Oka Crisis}}
Canada's treatment of [[First Nations]] people is governed by the [[Indian Act]]. Many indigenous people were [[Cultural assimilation|assimilated]] into the [[Canadian Indian residential school system]]. European settlers assumed the indigenous people needed saving; this is a form of "charitable racism".<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |last=Alfred |first=Taiaiake |location=Ontario |editor1=M. Cannon |editor2=L. Sunseri |publisher=Oxford Press |date=2011 |contribution=Colonial Stains on Our Existence |title=Racism, Colonialism, and Indigeneity}}</ref> In 1999 the Canadian government created an autonomous territory, [[Nunavut]], for the Inuit living in the Arctic and northernmost parts of the country. The Inuit compose 85% of the population of Nunavut, which represents a new level of [[self-determination]] for the indigenous people of Canada.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.un.org/WCAR/e-kit/indigenous.htm|title = Press kit: Issues – Racism against Indigenous peoples – World Conference Against Racism|work = United Nations|access-date = October 7, 2020|archive-date = February 25, 2019|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20190225234113/http://www.un.org/WCAR/e-kit/indigenous.htm|url-status = live}}</ref> In August 2008, [[McGill University]]'s Chancellor and International Olympic Committee representative [[Dick Pound|Richard Pound]] told ''[[La Presse (Canadian newspaper)|La Presse]]'': "We must not forget that 400 years ago, Canada was a land of [[Primitive culture|savages]], with scarcely 10,000 inhabitants of European origin, while in China, we're talking about a 5,000-year-old civilization", implying that the First Nations people were "uncivilized".<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.canada.com/topics/news/story.html?id=1acb6487-4f6c-4e03-abf2-f18e880f2a0d |title = Ex-Olympian Call Pound Racist |work = Canwest News Service |date = October 18, 2008 |access-date = October 7, 2020 |archive-date = March 18, 2016 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160318171100/http://www.canada.com/topics/news/story.html?id=1acb6487-4f6c-4e03-abf2-f18e880f2a0d |url-status = live }}</ref> The Canadian [[Indian Act]] helped inspire South Africa's [[apartheid]] policies.<ref>Gloria Galloway, [https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/chiefs-reflect-on-apartheid-and-first-nations-as-atleo-visits-mandela-memorial/article15902124/ "Chieft Reflect on Apartheid"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190502050752/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/chiefs-reflect-on-apartheid-and-first-nations-as-atleo-visits-mandela-memorial/article15902124/ |date=May 2, 2019 }}, ''The Globe and Mail'', 11 December 2013</ref>
In 2006, [[Amnesty International]] researched racism specific to Indigenous women in Canada.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.amnesty.ca/research/reports/stolen-sisters-a-human-rights-response-to-discrimination-and-violence-against-indig|title = Stolen Sister|date = 2006|accessdate = November 18, 2014|website = Amnesty.ca|publisher = |last = |first = |archive-date = November 29, 2014|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20141129032522/http://www.amnesty.ca/research/reports/stolen-sisters-a-human-rights-response-to-discrimination-and-violence-against-indig|url-status = live}}</ref> They report on the lack of basic human rights, discrimination, and violence against Indigenous women. [[First Nations]] women (age 25–44) with status under the [[Indian Act]] are five times more likely than other women of the same age to die as a result of violence.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.amnesty.ca/research/reports/stolen-sisters-a-human-rights-response-to-discrimination-and-violence-against-indig|title = Amnesty Stolen Sisters|date = 2006|accessdate = |website = Amnesty.ca|publisher = |last = |first = |archive-date = July 19, 2018|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20180719080557/https://www.amnesty.ca/research/reports/stolen-sisters-a-human-rights-response-to-discrimination-and-violence-against-indig|url-status = live}}</ref> From 1928 to the mid 1990s, Indigenous girls in the [[Canadian Indian residential school system|residential school system]] were subject to forced sterilization once they reached puberty. The number of sterilized girls is not known because the records were destroyed.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Conquest: Sexual Violence and American Genocide|last = Smith|first = Andrea|publisher = South End Press|year = 2005|isbn = |location = Cambridge, MA|pages = }}</ref> The numbers of Indigenous women and children gone missing or murdered within the next 10 years could reach 3,000.<ref name=":2" /> The issue of [[Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women|missing and murdered Indigenous women]] has been a social issue that has received a great deal of attention by the media, the Canadian government, and The United Nations Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination against Women. The estimate of missing and murdered women have ranged from 500 to 3000, depending on the time period being studied and the method of calculating this statistic. The reason for the increased attention on this issue is the representation of murdered indigenous women in crime statistics are not proportionate to the general population <ref>Michalke, C. (2015). Violence against Aboriginal women, a social phenomenon. Vancouver Island University Library. Retrieved: [[hdl:10613/2585|http://hdl.handle.net/10613/2585]] </ref> In 2006, a [[documentary film]] called [[Finding Dawn]] looks into the many missing and murdered Aboriginal women in Canada over the past three decades.<ref name="CSWS">{{cite web|url=http://csws.uoregon.edu/?p=1097 |title=Acclaimed Feminist Filmmaker To Screen "Finding Dawn" |publisher=[[University of Oregon]] |work=[[Center for the Study of Women in Society]] |accessdate=26 November 2009 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090508140428/http://csws.uoregon.edu/?p=1097 |archivedate=8 May 2009 }}</ref>
[[Aboriginal peoples in Canada|Indigenous]] people still have to deal with [[racism]] within Canada and the challenges that the communities face are often ignored.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/05/17/wab-kinew-systemic-racism-aboriginal-education_n_9829964.html|title=Wab Kinew Schools Us On Systemic Racism|website=The Huffington Post|access-date=2016-12-06|archive-date=December 10, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181210121902/https://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/05/17/wab-kinew-systemic-racism-aboriginal-education_n_9829964.html|url-status=live}}</ref> There are still very much negative stereotypes associated with Indigenous communities such as being freeloaders, drug addicts or dumb.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/09/30/aboriginal-stereotypes-portaits-lethbridge-kc-adams_n_12253100.html|title=Alberta Portrait Project Challenges Aboriginal Stereotypes|website=The Huffington Post|access-date=2016-12-06|archive-date=December 10, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181210120832/https://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/09/30/aboriginal-stereotypes-portaits-lethbridge-kc-adams_n_12253100.html|url-status=live}}</ref> Aboriginal people are more likely to feel [[Depression (mood)|depression]] due to several factors such as: poverty, loss of cultural identity, inadequate health care and more.
In 2020, staff at a hospital in the [[Quebec]] city of [[Joliette]] were shown on video mocking and making sexist remarks at an indigenous [[Atikamekw]] woman who eventually died. Indigenous leaders say the video exposes the grim realities of systemic racism that have long gone ignored or suppressed throughout Canada.<ref name=":35">{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/05/17/wab-kinew-systemic-racism-aboriginal-education_n_9829964.html|title=Canada: outcry after video shows hospital staff taunting dying Indigenous woman|website=The Guardian|access-date=2020-10-08|archive-date=December 10, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181210121902/https://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/05/17/wab-kinew-systemic-racism-aboriginal-education_n_9829964.html|url-status=live}}</ref>
=== [[Slavery_among_the_indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas#European_enslavement_of_Indigenous_people|Slavery of Aboriginals]] and [[Black Canadians]] === [[File:Ku Klux Klan at a gathering near Kingston, Ontario in 1927.jpg|thumb|Ku Klux Klan members, on foot and horseback, by a cross erected in a field near Kingston, Ontario in 1927]] There are records of slavery in some areas that later became Canada, dating from the 17th century. The majority of [[Slavery in Canada|Canadian slaves]] were [[First Nations|Aboriginal]],<ref name="Winks1997">{{cite book|last=Winks|first=Robin W.|title=The Blacks in Canada: A History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Eeh4L1CulqYC|year=1997|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press - MQUP|isbn=978-0-7735-1632-8|page=9}}</ref> and [[United Empire Loyalists]] brought slaves with them after leaving the [[United States]]. [[Marie-Joseph Angélique]] was one of New France's best-known slaves. While pregnant, she set her mistress' house on fire for revenge or to divert the attention away from her escape. She ran away with the father of her child, who was also a black slave and belonged to another owner. The fire that she started ended up burning part of Montreal and a large portion of the Hôtel-Dieu. Later on, she was caught and sentenced to death.

====Africville==== {{main|Africville}} {{see also|Black Nova Scotians}}
In [[Nova Scotia]], a community which mainly consisted of Black Canadians were forcibly removed and eventually razed between 1964 and 1967 after years of intentional neglect by the [[Government in Halifax, Nova Scotia|government]] in [[Halifax, Nova Scotia|Halifax]].<ref>{{Cite web|date=18 November 2017|title=TURNING POINTS: The Razing of Africville an epic failure in urban community renewal|url=http://thechronicleherald.ca/thenovascotian/1521817-turning-points-the-razing-of-africville-an-epic-failure-in-urban-community-re|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180215024507/http://thechronicleherald.ca/thenovascotian/1521817-turning-points-the-razing-of-africville-an-epic-failure-in-urban-community-re|archive-date=15 February 2018|access-date=14 February 2018|website=The Chronicle Herald}}</ref>
=== Jews === {{see also|History of Jews in Canada|MS St. Louis}} Jewish students were prohibited from studying at Canadian universities.<ref name=McGill>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mcgilldaily.com/2018/09/mcgills-1926-jewish-ban/|title=McGill's 1926 Jewish ban {{!}} The McGill Daily|language=en-US|access-date=2019-12-05|archive-date=August 12, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200812153422/https://www.mcgilldaily.com/2018/09/mcgills-1926-jewish-ban/|url-status=live}}</ref> Canada had restrictive policies towards Jewish immigration. in 1939, Jewish refugees escaping from WWII Europe aboard the MS St Louis were not allowed to enter Canada due to racist immigration policies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/anti-semitism|title=Anti-Semitism in Canada {{!}} The Canadian Encyclopedia|website=thecanadianencyclopedia.ca|access-date=2019-12-05|archive-date=August 7, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200807214216/https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/anti-semitism|url-status=live}}</ref> While government policies have changed, racism against Jews remains problematic. Hate crimes against Jews, also called violent [[antisemitism]], is the highest per capita recorded form of racism in Canada.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/n1/daily-quotidien/181129/dq181129a-eng.htm|title=The Daily — Police-reported hate crime, 2017|last=Government of Canada|first=Statistics Canada|date=2018-11-29|website=www150.statcan.gc.ca|access-date=2019-12-05|archive-date=September 16, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200916234347/https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/n1/daily-quotidien/181129/dq181129a-eng.htm|url-status=live}}</ref> This, despite Jews being a tiny minority of the population, only 1.1% of Canada's population in 2018.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.environicsinstitute.org/docs/default-source/project-documents/2018-survey-of-jews-in-canada/2018-survey-of-jews-in-canada---final-report.pdf?sfvrsn=2994ef6_2 |title=Archived copy |access-date=October 7, 2020 |archive-date=May 31, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200531000033/https://www.environicsinstitute.org/docs/default-source/project-documents/2018-survey-of-jews-in-canada/2018-survey-of-jews-in-canada---final-report.pdf?sfvrsn=2994ef6_2 |url-status=live }}</ref>
===[[Asian Canadians]]===
==== [[Indo-Canadians]] ==== {{see also|British Raj}} In 1914, Indians arriving in Canada were not allowed to enter despite being [[British subject|British subjects]] leading to the deaths of dozens of immigrants in the [[Komagata Maru incident|''Komagata Maru'' incident]].
==== [[Chinese Canadians]] ==== [[File:Chinatown riot VPL 940 (10463603965).jpg|thumb|right|Boarded windows and storefronts on Pender Street in [[Chinatown, Vancouver|Chinatown]] after the September 1907 riots]] Starting in 1858, [[Chinese people|Chinese]] "[[coolies]]" were brought to Canada to work in British Columbia in the mines and on the [[Canadian Pacific Railway]].{{sfn|Wilford|2011|p=28}} After anti-Chinese riots broke out in 1886, a "[[Chinese head tax in Canada|Chinese head tax]]" was implemented to curtail immigration from China. In 1907, the [[Anti-Oriental Riots (Vancouver)|Anti-Oriental Riots]] in [[Vancouver, British Columbia|Vancouver]] targeted Chinese and Japanese-owned businesses, and the Asiatic Exclusion League was formed to drive Asians out of the province. League members attacked Asians, resulting in numerous riots.{{sfn|Wilford|2011|p=28}} In 1923, the federal government passed the [[Chinese Immigration Act of 1923|Chinese Immigration Act]], commonly known as the ''Exclusion Act'', prohibiting most Chinese immigration.{{sfn|Wilford|2011|p=29}} The act was repealed in 1947,{{sfn|Melnyk|Seiler|2003|p=279}} but discrimination limiting non-European immigrants continued until 1967 when a points-based system was introduced to assess immigrants regardless of origin.
==== [[Japanese Canadians]] ==== [[File:JapaneseCanadian-Confiscating-Boat.jpg|thumb|A [[Royal Canadian Navy]] officer questions Canadian fishermen of Japanese descent as their boats were confiscated.]] {{See also|Japantown, Vancouver|Internment of Japanese Canadians}} Although a British–Japanese treaty guaranteed Japanese citizens freedom of travel, they were nevertheless subject to anti-Asian racism in Canada, though a slightly lesser degree at the time than the Chinese before World War II, as an informal agreement between the Japanese and Canadian governments limited Japanese immigration in the wake of the [[Anti-Oriental riots (Vancouver)|Vancouver anti-Asian riots]].{{sfn|Melnyk|Seiler|2003|p=279}}
In 1942, during [[World War II]], many Canadians of Japanese heritage—even those born in Canada— were forcibly [[Japanese-Canadian internment|moved to internment camps]] under the authority of the [[War Measures Act]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/m/article/japanese-canadians/|title=Japanese Canadians|newspaper=The Canadian Encyclopedia|access-date=2016-12-06|archive-date=January 19, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180119120305/http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/m/article/japanese-canadians/|url-status=live}}</ref> At first, many men were separated from their families and sent to road camps in Ontario and on the [[British Columbia]]–[[Alberta]] border. Small towns in the [[British Columbia|BC]] interior such as [[Greenwood, British Columbia|Greenwood]], [[Sandon, British Columbia|Sandon]], [[New Denver]] and [[Slocan, British Columbia|Slocan]] became internment camps for women, children and the aged. To stay together, Japanese–Canadian families chose to work in farms in [[Alberta]] and [[Manitoba]]. Those who resisted and challenged the orders of the Canadian government were rounded up by the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] and incarcerated in a barbed-wire prisoner-of-war camp in Angler, [[Ontario]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.japanesecanadianhistory.net/the_war_years.htm|title=JapaneseCanadianHistory.net Historical Overview|website=www.japanesecanadianhistory.net|access-date=2016-12-06|archive-date=November 8, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171108140759/http://www.japanesecanadianhistory.net/the_war_years.htm|url-status=live}}</ref> Japanese–Canadians fishing boats were also seized, with plans to drastically reduce fishing licenses from them and forcibly redistribute them for white Canadians.<ref name="r-m">[http://journals.sfu.ca/archivar/index.php/archivaria/article/view/12837/14056 Establishing Recognition of Past Injustices: Uses of Archival Records in Documenting the Experience of Japanese Canadians During the Second World War]. Roberts-Moore, Judith. Archivaria: The Journal of the Association of Canadian Archivists, 53 (2002).</ref> With government promises to return the land and properties seized during that time period, Japanese Canadians left their homes. This turned out to be untrue, as the seized possessions were resold and never returned to the Japanese Canadians. Unlike prisoners of war, who were protected by the [[Geneva Conventions|Geneva Convention]], Japanese–Canadians were forced to pay for their own internment.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://history.cbc.ca/histoire/?MIval=EpisContent.html&series_id=1&episode_id=14&chapter_id=3&page_id=3&lang=E |title=Japanese Internment |publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071221071212/http://history.cbc.ca/histoire/?MIval=EpisContent.html&series_id=1&episode_id=14&chapter_id=3&page_id=3&lang=E |archivedate=December 21, 2007 }}</ref>
